ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant?s senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  The Utility Systems Supervisor administers the City's safety and environmental policies. The Utility Systems Supervisor is responsible for various inspections of the City's facilities to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs.  These programs include hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The facility has been in operation since 1973 but the water treatment system was modified in 1997 and the aqueous ammonia system was added in late 2002.  The process is located at 14521 Lake Poway Road, Poway, CA 92064.  

The chlorine system for City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant consists of chlorine one-ton containers which are the storage vessels.  Chlorine gas is pulled from the one ton containers to the chlorinators through the vacuum regulator.  The chlorinators are equipped with water at the injectors and the resulting chlorine solution is distributed through rotameters to other water processes at the facility. 

Below provides a list of the chlorine equipment.

Chlorine One-Ton Containers (9) in the Storage Area
Vacuum Regulators (4) in the Storage Area
Chlorinators (4) in the Chlorinator Room (Chemical Building)
Injectors (4) in the Chlorinator Room (Chemical Building)
Injectors (2) in the Ammonia  Building
Scrubber System, Located at the south end of the facility..

The maximum quantity of chlorine that can be stored on site is 18,000 pounds.

The aqueous ammonia (20% concentration) is stored in a 6,000 gallon storage tank that

resides in a containment area.  A liquid pump draws the ammonia solution from the storage tank through plastic piping to the point of injection with softened water, which is then routed to the treated water to form chloramines in the water to reduce THM?s levels.  A combination pressure relief / vacuum breaker valve is located on top of the storage tank and relieves to a neutralization tank.  The valve protects the tank against excess pressure and vacuum conditions.

Below provides a list of the aqueous ammonia equipment.

Aqueous ammonia storage tank (1) in the Containment Basin
Neutralization Tank (1) (Stored in the Containment Basin)
Metering Pumps (2) in the Chemical Feed Building 
Flow Meter (1) in the Chemical Feed Building 
Ammonia Detector (1) in the Chemical Feed Building
Calibration Chamber (1) Inside Chemical Feed Building
Eye Wash / Safety Shower (2) Outside Feed Building and (1) Inside the Feed Building.

The maximum quantity of aqueous ammonia that can be stored on site is 40,000 pounds.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS - CHLORINE AND AQUEOUS AMMONIA

The chorine system at the City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations including the Uniform Mechanical Code, Uniform Building Code, and the Uniform Fire Code.  All of these codes serve to reduce the risk within the facility by specifying acceptable design criteria for the chorine system and on-site buildings.  In addition, the facility was designed in accordance with industry standards and with generally accepted engineering practices.

The aqueous ammonia system at the City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant is designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations including the 1997 Uniform Mechanical Code, Uniform Building Code, the Uniform Fire Code, the 1998 California Building Code, the American Society for Testing and Ma

terials, and the American Concrete Institute.  All of these codes serve to reduce the risk within the plant by specifying acceptable design criteria for the aqueous ammonia system and on-site buildings.  The system was designed and installed in accordance with industry standard and with generally accepted engineering practices. 

City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant has established a mechanical integrity program for maintaining and operating the chlorine and aqueous ammonia equipment and uses the Chlorine Manual from the Chlorine Institute as a basis.


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Based on the Hazard Assessment (February 6, 2004) review of the accident history, (February 1999 - February 2004), there have been no releases of chlorine that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 10 pounds or the California threshold of any release. In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from a chlorine release.  Also, there have been no releases of aqueous ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity or the California threshold of any release.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

If a release of chlorine or aqueous ammonia were to occur, the City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant's response plan is to call 911 in order to reach the Fire Department's HAZMAT team.  Employees will evacuate the facility to a point that is upwind of the hazard.  Evacuation drills are performed annually.  The last evacuation drill was performed on May 14, 2004.  The emergency response plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations.  It is reviewed annually to ensure that the plan is kept current.  


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The City of Poway has taken a pro-active approach to emergency response and safety at the Water Treat Plant.

The annual emergency response drills are documented and mitigation measures to improve the Team?s response are continuously being reviewed. City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant has implemented all recommendations from the initial technical studies, as well as all recommendations from the latest PSM/RMP Compliance Audit (June 24, 2002) and the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation (September 15, 2003). 

The Process Safety Management team is planning to complete several items over the next year as their continued effort to provide a safe work environment for the City employees.  These changes include the following items:

1.    Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2.    Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3.    Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4.    Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
